Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Advanced Multiplexed Structural Mass Spectrometer for Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation and support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Professor John McLean from Vanderbilt University and colleagues John Wikswo and Jody May will develop a multiplexed ion mobility-mass spectrometer (IM-MS) for rapid and comprehensive chemical analysis of highly complex systems in materials science to biology. The instrument will consist of eight spatially disparate channels of analysis including switchable multiplexed nanoelectrospray ionization (nESI) and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) sources. This multiplexed instrument will integrate the capabilities of eight separate IM-MS instruments into a single spectrometer platform and represents the first module of a 96 channel instrument that is suitable for extremely high throughput analyses of either liquids or solids. In addition to increasing analytical throughput, this IM-MS will improve sensitivity and limits-of-detection through combining the data from each channel.

Mass spectrometry (MS) is used to identify the chemical composition of a sample and determine its purity by measuring the mass of the molecular constituents in the sample after they are ionized and detected by the mass spectrometer. This widely used analytical technique is used to identify and quantify the chemical composition of a sample. The unique capabilities of this spatially multiplexed structural mass spectrometer will have significant and broad-reaching implications in areas ranging from nanotechnology to biofuels and systems biology. One of the grand challenges that these nascent fields face is the lack of suitable technologies capable of obtaining dynamic measurements of materials in both space and time. Although the primary focus will be instrumentation development, this project will provide novel interdisciplinary training opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, in state-of-the-art mass spectrometry, ion mobility spectrometry and other allied fields of research. Additionally, students will be trained as future instrument developers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The specific aim of this project was to design and construct a first-of-a-kind multiplexed ion mobility-mass spectrometer (IM-MS) based upon eight spatially separated ion analysis channels. Such an instrument would result in the next generation of analytical instrumentation and methodologies of significant importance in areas ranging from nanotechnology to biofuels to systems biology research. One of the grand challenges that face these nascent fields is the lack of suitable technologies for dynamically characterizing materials in both space and time. The instrumentation developed for this project represents a significant improvement in chemical analysis technology with regard to analytical throughput, sensitivity, and versatility. This technology is broadly applicable to high-throughput measurements of a large range of analytes present in biological samples. In addition, the high-throughput capabilities enable near real-time measurements of chemicals originating from viable biological samples such as cells, tissues, and organs, which makes it possible to obtain temporal information at sub-second resolutions. Because of the complexity of the instrumentation, it was necessary to incorporate several complex calculations in the underlying theoretical framework used to design the instrument.  As such, we completed extensive fluid dynamics and electric field simulations of ion trajectories under a combination of electrostatic and electrodynamic fields. The ion optics and vacuum system were designed using advanced computer-aided design and fabricated with online computer numeric control machining. Electrodynamic ion optics were developed on printed circuit board technology, and driven using off-the-shelf electronics.  The hardware incorporates a number of novel design elements that will drive future instrumentation efforts in diverse, but allied research avenues. Preliminary testing of the instrument is under way.

Broader Impacts: The instrument may provide an entirely new class of dynamic information about cell signaling and metabolism, in that the eight channels can be used for eight different upstream interrogations of the exometabolome from a common cell source, for example using isoelectric fractionation of different affinity chromatographies. The simultaneous measurement of multiple biochemical properties of the cellular exometabolome could have a profound impact on systems biology and toxicology. A significant aspect of this project was to train young scientists (both pre- and post-doctoral) in contemporary methods used to design, construct, and operate state-of-the-art analytical instrumentation. Research scientists trained in IM-MS and multiplexing techniques are in high demand, and advanced training is urgently needed. The opportunity to develop this instrument brought together trainees from diverse educational backgrounds, with degree focuses in chemistry, physics, biomedical and materials engineering, and computer science, among others.  Two postdoctoral scholars and five Vanderbilt graduate students were directly involved in this project, which also provided, under separate funding, novel interdisciplinary training opportunities for students participating in the Systems Biology and Bioengineering Undergraduate Research Experience (SyBBURE) program at Vanderbilt and for students from Fisk University, an HBCU in Nashville. An additional six undergraduate students were directly involved in various aspects of this project, supported by these other means.
